answers.explanation: The internal thoracic artery provides the major blood supply to the mammary gland.
About 75% of the lymph from the breast drains into the axillary lymph nodes.
The mammary gland is a modified apocrine sweat gland.
The suspensory ligaments of Cooper provide structural support to the breast.
The axillary vein receives most of the venous drainage from the mammary gland.
Prolactin stimulates milk production in the mammary gland.
Oxytocin stimulates the contraction of myoepithelial cells, leading to milk ejection.
The mammary gland develops from the ectoderm.
The nipple is typically located at the level of the 4th intercostal space.
The intercostal nerve (T4) provides sensory innervation to the nipple.
Peau d'orange is caused by lymphatic obstruction, leading to skin dimpling.
The retromammary space allows movement of the breast over the pectoralis major muscle.
The long thoracic nerve supplies the serratus anterior, and its injury causes scapular winging.
Montgomery glands secrete lubricating substances to protect the nipple during breastfeeding.
The upper outer quadrant has the highest incidence of breast cancer due to the high density of glandular tissue.
